ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had semi-frequent thesis checkins but much of the work was done on our own time.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class helps you learn how to manage long essays, how to conduct research, and how to implement feedback on a regular basis.

A more in-depth understanding of the IRB process, and senior writing process. A better understanding of research methods and what tools are our there to assist you in doing research. How to make my own research problem and write a literature review.

I learned a lot about how to think about conveying research, including learning how to start diving into the literature and strategies for finding relevant literature, and understanding how to frame a research question in writing and what elements are important to include / exclude.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: This class does a good job at forcing you to continue doing research with its deadlines.  The check ins were also good at reassuring me that I was on track. 

Weaknesses: I wish I received more feedback on a regular basis.

Strengths: Paced in a very manageable way, not reading heavy, let's you focus on your research goals.
Weaknesses: Can't think of any.
This is a great way to work on your thesis! The class assignments set deadlines and the other students are very helpful for providing useful insights and reflections on your work.
No suggestions for improvement! Both Prof. Wyrtzen and Hannah provided great feedback and led the course well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We met up once on cross campus which was nice, besides that, the professor kept class relatively short which was much appreciated.
I thought it was great! We even had a socially distanced meet-up in the warmer days of the Fall.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to any Sociology major because you have to take it.
Sure, if you want to do your own independent sociological research.
Yes! It would be a mistake to not take this if you plan on writing a thesis

Yes, absolutely! This course is a strength of the sociology major, as you're led through the steps of starting to conduct your own research and translating your research question into writing and research findings. Plus, it's always interesting / motivating to hear about other students' senior thesis research projects. Prof. Wyrtzen and Hannah have been excellent guides through this process.
